metadata.synopsis:
Default dialogue with Helsik. They are a trader and warlock in lower city. They grant us the ingredients to perform the ritual to the House of Hope. 

HELPFUL DEBUG COMMANDS:
oe LOW_GetItemsFromGortash - learn about Helsik from Gortash's note
oe LOW_KnowAllHelsik - learn that Helsik is a diabolist and that they know the way to the HoH
oe LOW_PortalHouseOfHope - set up the interactable HoH portal without having to do the ritual
metadata.how_to_trigger: Making click on S_LOW_Helsik 299a1c00-ff53-415e-ad8e-9bcbbae55597 at the Diabolist House.

32.speaker: Helsik
32.text: I welcome thee to the Devil's Fee, where every hellish curio is a - Oh. It's you.

69.speaker: Helsik
69.text: Your little scrote of a friend left this on my floor the last time you visited.
69.context: CinematicNodeContext: Helsik gives you Scleritas' hat. The DU takes it, non-plussed

299.speaker: Helsik
299.text: I presume you have returned to re-engage my services?

133.speaker: Player
133.text: I've never met you in my life.

111.speaker: Helsik
111.text: You... forgot what we did? I find that hard to believe.

103.speaker: Helsik
103.text: But, if you speak truth, perhaps I could... Jog that lazy memory of yours?

322.speaker: Player
322.text: My memory is quite beyond hope, don't bother.

135.speaker: Helsik
135.text: Very well. How else may I be of service?

278.speaker: Helsik
278.text: I welcome thee to the Devil's Fee - That's the spiel I give the more mundane customers.

55.speaker: Helsik
55.text: It's a front, really. I sell tacky, devil-shaped knick-knacks to plebians, and a more... refined set of wares to discerning customers. Like yourself.

137.speaker: Player
137.text: Shit, this again. Remind me of our past association?

205.speaker: Helsik
205.text: I am afraid that I cannot take you back to Mephistopheles' vaults. That place is now locked tighter than Lord Mammon's coinpurse.

25.speaker: Helsik
25.text: I have, however, recently found a delightful new place I could sneak you into. Tell me, what do you know of the devil Raphael?

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Bring him the Crown of Karsus, or he shall sup on my soul. Etc. Etc.

276.speaker: Helsik
276.text: Ah, so you and Raphael have chatted recently? How... unusual.

128.speaker: Helsik
128.text: You remember the Crown of Karsus, yes?

250.speaker: Player
250.text: My wizard has spoken of little else, of late.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: I've heard of it - seems like everyone is after this crown.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: Why not? Let's say I do.

240.speaker: Helsik
240.text: I should hope so - last time you and Lord Gortash were here I charged you both a pretty penny to help steal it.

199.speaker: Helsik
199.text: I do enjoy a good tangent. I have found a way to slip the latch to his house, if you wish to leap into Avernus one more time. The crown seemed to interest you after all.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: Raphael must have all kinds of secrets in his House, and I want to undress them.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: Break into the House? If we were found, I doubt we'd come back.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: If I managed it before, I can pull it off again.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: I've forgotten every single thing I've ever done before a few tendays ago.

316.speaker: Helsik
316.text: You... don't recall? Odd. I refer to the Crown of Karsus you and Lord Enver Gortash stole from Avernus with my help. The devil Raphael desires it.

169.speaker: Player
169.text: Not as much as I'd like.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: Ah. Him again. Why is it always him?

39.speaker: Player
39.text: Your wares! Bring them before me!

187.speaker: Helsik
187.text: My most perceptive prospective customer... Welcome back.

182.speaker: Player
182.text: With regards to the House of Hope...

132.speaker: Player
132.text: Can you break me into the House of Hope?

102.speaker: Player
102.text: We have unfinished business - let's continue where we left off.

16.speaker: Player
16.text: I want more information about your business with Gortash.

325.speaker: Helsik
325.text: Well, I'm loathe to fully repeat myself... so I'll give you the whole tale. For a price, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_3_01f129ea-b4dc-44b6-8154-9a948f876a82])

84.speaker: Helsik
84.text: Did I threaten you? Did I force the coin from your purse to mine? No. Pay up. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_3_01f129ea-b4dc-44b6-8154-9a948f876a82])

155.speaker: Player
155.text: Never mind. Just show me your wares.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: No, you're not getting more of my money.

85.speaker: Helsik
85.text: Then you'll hear no more of my tale.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: I want to know about Gortash's dealings in the hells.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: I have the money. Show me how to get to the House of Hope. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]g)

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I have the money. Show me how to get to the House of Hope. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Show me your wares. The good stuff.

208.speaker: Helsik
208.text: Trips to the hells are usually one-way. Especially when the traveller causes the kind of trouble you did.

123.speaker: Helsik
123.text: I knew you were a thief. Didn't realise you were a killer.

270.speaker: Helsik
270.text: Raphael's death is already causing quite a stir across the hells - it's a rare thing for a mortal to slay a devil of his stature.

72.speaker: Helsik
72.text: In all the excitement, I hope you didn't forget our bargain. Do you have the Gauntlets?

59.speaker: Helsik
59.text: Hand them over, and our deal is done.

154.speaker: Helsik
154.text: That can be arranged. If there's enough coin on the table, Mammon permits almost anything.

354.speaker: Helsik
354.text: A handsome fee. The Gauntlets are yours to keep.

174.speaker: Helsik
174.text: There's nothing Mammon likes less than a welcher. Get the hell out and never come back.

338.speaker: Helsik
338.text: Then we have reached the end of our negotiations.

323.speaker: Helsik
323.text: Your coin is always welcome here, and so are you, devil-slayer.

211.speaker: Helsik
211.text: Is this a joke? You can't give me what you don't have.

360.speaker: Helsik
360.text: That invalidates our deal, I'm afraid. I fulfilled my part of the bargain, so you owe me the fee I proposed initially.

67.speaker: Helsik
67.text: I can see why your acquaintance with Raphael ended so violently - you're not a very convincing liar.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: Everything I took from the House is mine.

255.speaker: Player
255.text: I just killed a devil in his own home. You really don't want to test my patience.

8.speaker: Helsik
8.text: Not a subtle point, but well made. Keep the Gauntlets. Your threats aren't necessary, but your coin is still welcome, devil-slayer.

340.speaker: Helsik
340.text: That doesn't make you dangerous, it makes you a liability. Get out of here before you test my patience.

40.speaker: Helsik
40.text: I'm impressed. And just a little bit intimidated.

209.speaker: Helsik
209.text: I welcome thee to the Devil's Fee, where every hellish curio's a rarity! So merry be - and shop with glee.

178.speaker: Karlach
178.text: Oh no - definitely something up with this one. Trust me.
178.context: NodeContext: Karlach has a bad feeling about a very chipper shopkeeper (and she's right).

44.speaker: Narrator
44.text: *Raphael's warlock, Korrilla, mentioned a diabolist who aided Gortash. This cheerful woman doesn't seem the likeliest candidate.*

365.speaker: Player
365.text: Curios don't interest me. I'm interested in the hells themselves - a place called the House of Hope in particular.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Ever met an orthon? I have - he told me you're a diabolist.

282.speaker: Player
282.text: Can you get me into the House of Hope?

257.speaker: Player
257.text: Raphael told me the Crown of Karsus was stolen from Mephistopheles - were you involved with that?

14.speaker: Player
14.text: Did you help Lord Gortash retrieve some hellish curios by any chance?

213.speaker: Helsik
213.text: You must be awfully familiar with our esteemed Archduke to know about a thing like that.

363.speaker: Player
363.text: I know you're a diabolist who worked for Gortash. What did you do for him?

277.speaker: Helsik
277.text: Interesting. How exactly are you and our esteemed Archduke acquainted?

119.speaker: Player
119.text: I happened upon some of his correspondence that mentioned you dealings with him.
119.context: InternalNodeContext: We can learn this by reading the reports from Ninefingers or her necromancy book.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: I'm intimately familiar with the lining of his pockets.

37.speaker: Helsik
37.text: Truly. That's remarkable. I like to deal with remarkable people. Very well.

284.speaker: Player
284.text: It's your acquaintance with him I'm interested in - I found his name in your ledger.

20.speaker: Helsik
20.text: Likewise. Well, less of a colleague, more of a contractor - but I digress.

108.speaker: Helsik
108.text: You seek answers, Lord Mammon seeks coin. I will happily mediate - make me an offer.

12.speaker: Karlach
12.text: Mammon! I knew it. I did!
12.context: NodeContext: She already mentioned she had a bad feeling about this lady. Turns out she was right - she serves a devil called Mammon. Karlach isn't pleased about this but is glad she was right. Slightly comic, like she's expecting someone to challenge the fact that she knew it was Mammon (like saying 'I knew it!' after hearing an answer on jeopardy).

189.speaker: Player
189.text: Toss a coin to the diabolist.

349.speaker: Helsik
349.text: Ahah. Ahah. Ahah. Quite the fitting token. Let it not be said that Lord Mammon's servant does not deal with paupers.

74.speaker: Helsik
74.text: But I'm afraid you'll need to offer an awful lot more than that. I'll be keeping the coin, though, of course.

275.speaker: Helsik
275.text: Hmmm... The King of Avarice accepts your humble offering.

58.speaker: Helsik
58.text: A generous donation... The King of Avarice's pockets are most pleased.

233.speaker: Player
233.text: Actually I'll just take a look at your usual wares, if you don't mind.

292.speaker: Player
292.text: It's customary for any salesperson to offer a free sample.

202.speaker: Helsik
202.text: The first hit's free, eh? Fine - I'll humour you, mortal. Just this once.

324.speaker: Helsik
324.text: You stand before Mammon's Picklock. Latchkeeper of the Nine Hells. My business is not information, nor hellish curios, not really.

311.speaker: Helsik
311.text: I break people into the Hells. That's my thing.

134.speaker: Helsik
134.text: I can reveal to you that I opened a portal for Lord Gortash.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: Where in the hells did the portal go?

65.speaker: Helsik
65.text: My word... This is embarrassing. Perhaps I should have explained our terms better.

10.speaker: Helsik
10.text: You asked what I did for Lord Gortash, you paid the fee, and I answered you. Our pact is complete. Would you like to make another transaction?

230.speaker: Player
230.text: How much to tell me everything about your dealings with Gortash?

227.speaker: Helsik
227.text: Adjusting for inflation, the appreciable value of knowledge, Lord Mammon's tithe... A-ha. There we are. ([LOW_DevilsFee_GortashInfoPayment_4feace82-e2ce-a19d-967c-2a346b2cf96d])

2.speaker: Helsik
2.text: That 'something' was the inimitable Crown of Karsus. Gortash absconded with it - catching the interest of a devil named Raphael.

7.speaker: Helsik
7.text: Then to piecemeal information we return. You wish for more knowledge, make me an offer.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: Toss a single coin to the diabolist.

344.speaker: Helsik
344.text: Now now. That would be but a drop in Mammon's oceanic coffers - you can do better.

343.speaker: Helsik
343.text: Oh yes, I should think that'll do deliciously.

352.speaker: Helsik
352.text: Lord Gortash wanted to steal something from Mephistopheles, so I punched a portal into the Archdevil's dusty vaults.

207.speaker: Helsik
207.text: And then I... Gosh, my fickle memory fails. If only something would jog it.
207.context: CinematicNodeContext: Helisik puts out their hand,

327.speaker: Helsik
327.text: I mean... I suppose that'll do. Stingy bastard.

310.speaker: Helsik
310.text: Yes, you are quite correct. The Crown of Karsus left the Vault, and an opportunity opened for a devil named Raphael.

267.speaker: Helsik
267.text: Gortash stole the Crown of Karsus. Pissed off Mephistopheles, but rather intrigued another devil by the name Raphael.

300.speaker: Helsik
300.text: You rascals stole the Crown of Karsus. Pissed off Mephistopheles to no end. I expect you'll pay the price for that one day.

190.speaker: Helsik
190.text: You also attracted the attention of another devil: Raphael.

272.speaker: Helsik
272.text: His House of Hope is furnished with a great deal of treasures, many related to Karsus. But alas, he lacks the crown itself.

297.speaker: Narrator
297.text: *The Crown of Karsus? If the diabolist is to be believed, this would be no ordinary Netherese relic. It could command the power of the gods themselves. Or the Hells, if Raphael gets hold of it.*

104.speaker: Helsik
104.text: He's rather ambitious. One can only wonder what he has planned for the Crown. The answers to that can probably be found within his house...

191.speaker: Karlach
191.text: Let's poke around the rat's nest. Maybe set it on fire on the way out.

204.speaker: Lae'zel
204.text: Looks like we owe Raphael a semi-friendly visit.

286.speaker: Shadowheart
286.text: Perhaps it's time we paid Raphael a visit.

334.speaker: Astarion
334.text: Then perhaps we should drop by and surprise Raphael? It'd make a nice change.

220.speaker: Wyll
220.text: Looks like we owe Raphael a housecall.

302.speaker: Gale
302.text: I think it's about time we imposed ourselves on Raphael's hospitality for a change.

350.speaker: Halsin
350.text: Then to Raphael's house we must go.

83.speaker: Jaheira
83.text: Time for a social call, then. I'm sure Raphael makes for a wonderful host.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: Can you help me break into the House of Hope?

260.speaker: Helsik
260.text: What a fascinating proposition. Ludicrous, of course, but fascinating nevertheless.

162.speaker: Helsik
162.text: Very well. If you wish to die in Avernus, that's your business. Mine is charging you for it.

252.speaker: Helsik
252.text: Of course, such a task will require quite the substantial donation to Lord Mammon's coffers. ([LOW_DevilsFee_ExpensiveHoH_b64a3173-46d0-e663-eaf6-ee900355256d])

229.speaker: Helsik
229.text: Such a task would be tantamount to suicide. Do not even entertain it.

161.text: Such a task would be tantamount to suicide. And for what? The devil has nothing that you need.

315.speaker: Helsik
315.text: Why... The risk almost seems worth it when there's such pretty coins involved.
315.context: NodeContext: they get distracted, enamoured by the gold, almost wistful

86.speaker: Player
86.text: I don't have that much money.

171.speaker: Helsik
171.text: Then get out of my sight - and don't come back until your pockets drag with gold.
171.context: NodeContext: deeply insulted by the player's cheek

285.speaker: Player
285.text: I don't have that much money.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: Waive the fee and I'll add one of Raphael's artefacts to your collection.

218.speaker: Player
218.text: I'm a skilled thief - give me free passage I'll bring you back a 'souvenir'.

96.speaker: Helsik
96.text: You put me in a difficult position, mortal.

232.speaker: Helsik
232.text: You are almost certain to fail. Almost. And so, there is a chance you might succeed.

326.speaker: Helsik
326.text: Fine. I'd like to be able to carry all of my precious stock without the need of a team of oxen.

120.speaker: Helsik
120.text: There are Gauntlets of Hill Giant Strength within the House of Hope. Free passage, and you fetch them for me. Deal?

321.speaker: Helsik
321.text: Allow me to outline how this is going to work.

356.speaker: Helsik
356.text: First, you were never here. We never spoke.

268.speaker: Helsik
268.text: Second. You will perform the rites yourself - I want absolute deniability. Here's the grimoire and necessary components.
268.context: NodeContext: helsik returns to a more serious mode of address here

342.speaker: Helsik
342.text: Take this key, too. It unlocks the ritual room upstairs. There's a blood circle already drawn. Don't ask whose blood.

328.speaker: Narrator
328.text: *Along with the grimoire and components, Helsik hands you a note containing precise instructions for performing the ritual.*

21.speaker: Helsik
21.text: Finally, you were never here. That is of utmost import to remember. Now - begone.

82.speaker: Helsik
82.text: Very well. Here is the... What? I couldn't have misplaced... I've been robbed.

62.speaker: Helsik
62.text: OUT! The shop is closed. You and everyone else can go to hell - WITHOUT my help.

274.speaker: Helsik
274.text: My time is money, and you've wasted too much of it. Get out of my sight.

304.speaker: Player
304.text: You'll halve that price or I'll halve you.

51.speaker: Helsik
51.text: Far be it from me to overlook reason, reflected in the edge of a blade.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: Cut the price or I cut you into little pieces. CHOOSE.

318.speaker: Helsik
318.text: Let me tell you what happens if Raphael even suspects I'm poking around his home.

301.speaker: Helsik
301.text: I'll be scattered across the Hells like a broken snuffbox. The price stays. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

170.speaker: Player
170.text: Look, we both know your patron doesn't need that much. Lower the price.

228.speaker: Helsik
228.text: For a fellow diabolist? I can stoop lower. Once.

243.speaker: Helsik
243.text: I will grant a discount - a final discount, mind you. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])

305.speaker: Helsik
305.text: Who died and made you the expert on Mammon's expectant pockets? I certainly didn't. The price stays. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

127.speaker: Player
127.text: I already paid you too much. You are ripping me off.

320.speaker: Helsik
320.text: Correction dear. Lord Mammon is ripping you off. It's sort of his thing.

164.speaker: Player
164.text: That's a steep sum - I need some time to mull this over.

166.speaker: Helsik
166.text: Mull, or don't mull. It matters not to me. If you have coin, return. If not - don't.

361.speaker: Player
361.text: Well, that was interesting, but I'd just like to see your wares.

77.speaker: Helsik
77.text: Now you've seen what I have for thee - remember, discretion is key at the Devil's Fee.

195.speaker: Helsik
195.text: Coin and time most fortuitously spent.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: That information wasn't worth what I paid.

5.speaker: Helsik
5.text: And yet you paid anyway. What a terrible cosmic coincidence.

346.speaker: Minsc
346.text: Then I shall brush out Boo's fur - for we are going a-visiting.
346.context: NodeContext: You've been told that the secret to this whole conspiracy lies in a devil's residence - you're not even questioning tha that's where you're going next.

115.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
115.text: We should infiltrate the devil's home. I have always dreamed of visiting the hells.

280.speaker: Helsik
280.text: My, what deep pockets you have.

298.speaker: Player
298.text: My offer is - let me be a regular customer. I'd like to trade.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: Let's keep this simple. I'd just like to trade.

56.speaker: Helsik
56.text: I could remind you that you sought me, not vice versa. But why would I. I shall leave you in your blissful ignorance.

221.speaker: Helsik
221.text: Well, adjusting for inflation... appreciable value of knowledge but factoring in a dead-as-doornails Archduke... There we are. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_7_4f22f91f-28ec-8f22-c546-1f8b69a2725a])

144.speaker: Player
144.text: Perhaps a more banal transaction. May I see your wares?

266.speaker: Player
266.text: What business did Gortash have in the Hells?

13.speaker: Player
13.text: Raphael told me the Crown of Karsus was stolen from Mephistopheles - were you involved with that?

151.speaker: Helsik
151.text: Ra-pha-el? That sounds vaguely familiar, but I have a terrible memory for names. The only thing that jogs it is coin.
151.context: NodeContext: Sounding out the syllables of Raphael individually as if trying to remember if she's heard the name before, in an exaggerated performative manner

175.speaker: Helsik
175.text: There's no fun in that - so I think not. Make an offer, mortal.

341.speaker: Player
341.text: You know, any saleswoman worth her salt offers a free sample.

64.speaker: Helsik
64.text: Ah how cute. You tried that last time too.

139.speaker: Helsik
139.text: You want answers, you pay. Just like everyone else. Mammon is nothing if not egalitarian.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: Material wealth is a vain illusion. If you seek meaning and purpose, try compassion - give us a hint.

94.speaker: Helsik
94.text: You're telling me wealth is an illusion? What part of 'Mammon worshipper' do you not understand?

160.speaker: Player
160.text: Coin will do your corpse no good. SPEAK.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: I'm also of the pact-bound persuasion - don't suppose I can have a free sample?

163.speaker: Player
163.text: I'm something of a diabolist myself - perhaps you could spare a little free knowledge?

196.speaker: Player
196.text: We were lovers. It was all very steamy.

73.speaker: Helsik
73.text: My, what a juicy morsel. I didn't think he liked your type. Anyway...

214.speaker: Helsik
214.text: My my... touchy subject I see. Very well.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: Your hoard of genuine infernal items is impressive - show me the really good stuff.

347.speaker: Helsik
347.text: Well well - it's been a while since I've had such discerning custom. Here, you may browse my more... curated selection.

168.speaker: Player
168.text: Let's see what you've got on offer.

262.speaker: Player
262.text: I found some interesting reading material downstairs. You're a diabolist, it seems.

210.speaker: Helsik
210.text: Begone. The Devil's Fee is closed for business.

303.speaker: Helsik
303.text: My apologies, your eminentness, but the Devil's Fee is closed for business.

312.speaker: Helsik
312.text: I can feel the heat from that portal all the way down here. Keep it open as long as you need, but be sure nothing follows you through.

319.speaker: Helsik
319.text: Need anything before you head back to the hells?

71.speaker: Player
71.text: I've got a pair of gauntlets for you - still warm from Raphael's vault.

314.speaker: Helsik
314.text: Welcome back, devil-slayer. What can I do for you?

336.speaker: Helsik
336.text: How may I be of further assistance?

339.speaker: Helsik
339.text: Your esteemedness returns! O joyous hour.
